<!-- Auto-generated by zod-args-parser -->

# listy

A tiny in-memory list tool for parser demonstration

**Example:**

```bash
listy --uppercase true apple banana
```

## Options:

### `--help, -h` _optional_

Show help information

**Example:**

```bash
listy --help
```

### `--version` _optional_

Show version

### `--uppercase` _optional_

Convert added items to uppercase

**Example:**

```bash
listy --uppercase true apple banana
```

### `--tag <tag>` _optional_

Attach a tag to each added item

**Example:**

```bash
listy --tag fruit apple banana
```

### `--limit <number>` _optional_

Limit number of items added

**Example:**

```bash
listy --limit 1 apple banana cherry
```

## Arguments:

### `1st argument`

Items to add

## Subcommands:

### process [options]

Simulate processing data

**Example:**

```bash
argplay process --name "test" --count 5 --tags tag1;tag2;tag3 --verbose
```

#### Options:

#### `--name, -n <string>`

The name to process

#### `--count, -c <number>` _optional_

The number of times to process

**default:** `1`

#### `--tags, -t <list>`

tags separated by semicolon `;`

**Example:**

```bash
--tags tag1;tag2;tag3
```

#### `--custom` _optional_


#### `--verbose, -v` _optional_

Enable verbose mode

#### `--log, -l` _optional_

Enable verbose mode

---

### convert &lt;source&gt; &lt;destination&gt;

Simulate file conversion

**Example:**

```bash
argplay convert "input.txt" "output.csv" --format csv --overwrite
```

#### Options:

#### `--format, -f <string>`


> hello  
hi

The **format** to convert to `json` or `csv`.

```console
$ argplay convert <source> <destination> --format <string>
```

**Example:**

```bash
json or csv
```

#### `--overwrite` _optional_

**Overwrite** the existing file

**default:** `false`

#### `--verbose, -v` _optional_

Enable verbose mode

#### `--log, -l` _optional_

Enable verbose mode

#### Arguments:

#### `destination`

Source file

#### `destination`

Destination file

---

### configure, config

Simulate configuring the system

**Example:**

```bash
argplay configure --no-enable-logging --mode production
```

#### Options:

#### `--enable-logging` _optional_

Enable logging

**default:** `true`

**Example:**

```bash
--enable-logging=false
--no-enable-logging
```

#### `--mode, -m <choice>`

Choose the mode (development, production, testing)

---

### count, list

Print a list of items provided by the user

---

### help &lt;command&gt;

Print help message for command

#### Arguments:

#### `command` _optional_

Command to print help for
